Scheme 1 Structure, synthesis, and electrocatalytic application of RE alloy nanomaterials. Review Rare earth alloy nanomaterials in electrocatalysis Yifei Li Xilin Yuan Ping Wang Lulin Tang Miao He Pangen Li Jiang Li ⁎ Zhenxing Li ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, College of New Energy and Materials, China University of Petroleum (Beijing), Beijing 102249, China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing College of New Energy and Materials China University of Petroleum (Beijing) Beijing 102249 China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, College of New Energy and Materials, China University of Petroleum (Beijing), Beijing 102249, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Description. Structure of rare earth alloy nanomaterials and their application in electrochemistry are reviewed. With the rapid development of society and economy, the excessive consumption of fossil energy has led to the global energy and environment crisis. In order to explore the sustainable development of new energy, research based on electrocatalysis has attracted extensive attention in the academic circle. The main challenge in this field is to develop nano-catalysts with excellent electrocatalytic activity and selectivity for target products. The state of the active site in catalyst plays a decisive role in the activity and selectivity of the reaction. In order to design efficient and excellent catalysts, it is an effective means to adjust the electronic structure of catalysts. Electronic effects are also called ligand effects. By alloying with rare earth (RE) elements, electrons can be redistributed between RE elements and transition metal elements, achieving accurate design of the electronic structure of the active site in the alloy. Because of the unique electronic structure of RE, it has been paid attention in the field of catalysis. The outermost shell structure of RE elements is basically the same as that of the lower shell, except that the number of electrons in the 4f orbital is different, but the energy level is similar, so their properties are very similar. When RE elements form compounds, both the f electrons in the outermost shell and the d electrons in the lower outer shell can participate in bonding. In addition, part of the 4f electrons in the third outer shell can also participate in bonding. In order to improve the performance of metal catalysts, alloying provides an effective method to design advanced functional materials. RE alloys can integrate the unique electronic structure and catalytic behavior of RE elements into metal materials, which not only provides an opportunity to adjust the electronic structure and catalytic activity of the active component, but also enhances the structural stability of the alloy and is expected to significantly improve the catalytic performance of the catalyst. From the perspective of electronic and catalytic activity, RE elements have unique electronic configuration and lanthanide shrinkage effect. Alloying with RE elements will make the alloy have more abundant electronic structure, activity, and spatial arrangement, effectively adjusting the reaction kinetics of the electrochemical process of the catalyst. In this paper, the composition, structure, synthesis of RE alloys and their applications in the field of electrocatalysis are summarized, including the hydrogen evolution reaction, the oxygen evolution reaction, the oxygen reduction reaction, the methanol oxidation reaction, the ethanol oxidation reaction, and other catalytic reactions. At the same time, the present challenges of RE alloy electrocatalytic materials are summarized and their future development direction is pointed out. In the field of electrocatalysis, the cost of catalyst is too high and the stability is not strong. Therefore, the testing process should be related to the actual application, and the test method should be standardized, so as to carry forward the field of electrocatalysis. Keywords Rare earth Alloy nanomaterials Electrocatalysis Preparation methods Hydrogen evolution reaction Oxygen reduction reaction Methanol oxidation reaction Ethanol oxidation reaction 1 Introduction Recently, the electrocatalysis field has received much attention due to its environmentally friendly properties [1,2]. At present, the precious metal is the most used catalyst in electrocatalysis. However, because of the high price, low storage capacity, and inactivation caused by long-term use, the commercial application of precious metal electrocatalysts has not been widely developed and utilized. Metal alloying is one of the most promising strategies for developing catalysts with both high durability and enhanced activity [3–5]. Compared with the single metal catalysts, the addition of foreign metals results in the formation of polymetallic nanocrystals that can change the electronic structure and spatial arrangement pattern. In past work, the researchers reduced the load of precious metals in the catalyst in various ways to reduce the cost of the catalyst. For example, the high specific surface area carbon carrier is loaded with nano-sized single metal particles, and the core-shell structural nanoparticles with non-noble metal core layer and active metal shell layer are designed. The active components are alloyed with transition metals or rare earth (RE) metals (La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Gd, Sm, Eu, etc.). In these methods, alloy catalysts can simultaneously reduce the number of active components and greatly improve the electrochemical activity of catalysts, which has high research value. The electron interaction between alloying elements can significantly regulate the adsorption energy of the reactants to optimize the reaction path. Due to the overlap of electron conduction bands, alloying changes the electronic structure of the precious metal so that part of the electron transfer of the precious metal leads to a shift in the d-band center relative to the Fermi level. RE alloys have very negative formation energy, much lower than transition metal alloys, and thus have a more stable structure than ordinary transition metal alloy catalysts. Pt-RE alloys exhibit the highest activity among all reported oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) catalysts. Some RE elements and precious metals can form intermetallic electron compounds, and their special cell structure can reduce the work function of the alloys. Alloying the active components with RE elements can make the alloy have richer mechanical properties, electronic structure, and spatial arrangement, with adjustable surface reaction kinetics and better reactivity. The structure of catalyst determines the performance of catalyst. In order to obtain RE alloy electrocatalyst with stable structure and excellent performance, it is very necessary to design the composition and structure of catalyst rationally. The structure of catalyst includes morphology structure and bulk phase structure. For alloy electrocatalysts, almost all RE elements can be used as part of the alloy material except the most typical alloys consisting of transition metals, but only a portion of RE alloys have been successfully used in the field of electrocatalysis. In addition, the alloying energy of lanthanide RE alloy is lower than that of transition metal alloy, and low alloying energy can make RE atoms in catalyst difficult to diffuse to the surface of alloy catalyst, effectively enhancing the structural stability of catalyst. The activity of catalyst has an important relationship with the coordination environment of its active center. According to the expected performance and application, the alloy structure with controllable active center and stoichiometric ratio can be designed to construct functional RE alloy catalysts. The structural diversity of RE alloys enables them to have a wide range of functions. The excellent performance of alloy catalysts can be attributed to the electronic and structural effects that occur when RE elements are alloyed with other elements. In RE alloys, the electric charge transferred by atoms through metal bonding changes the overall electronic structure and catalytic performance of the catalyst. Alloying also changes the spatial structure of atoms, such as strain and lattice size. Alloying with RE elements to change the microstructure and phase composition of active metals is an effective strategy to change their properties. In addition, the electronic interactions and synergies between alloying elements can significantly optimize the adsorption and desorption of reaction intermediates [6]. Compared with other alloy catalysts [7], the RE alloy shows a higher alloying enthalpy, which effectively inhibits dealloying during the catalytic process and greatly increases the stability [8]. Furthermore, the larger atomic radius and lanthanide shrinkage lead to a compression effect on the catalyst surface after alloying, which can optimize the change in binding energy during the catalytic process [9]. In addition, the unique 4f orbital structure leads to strong electronic synergy between each component. Compared with traditional alloy catalytic materials, RE alloy catalytic materials have the characteristics of more active sites, better dispersion and more uniform pore size distribution, high catalytic activity, large specific surface area, good stability, high selectivity, and short processing cycle. Compared with traditional precious metal catalysts, RE catalytic materials have strong advantages in terms of resource abundance, cost, preparation process, and performance. The preparation conditions required for the RE alloy to have a uniform size at the nanometer scale are very demanding. There are two main reasons: (1) Due to the ultra-low reduction potential of RE elements (−1.9 to 2.38 V), it is more difficult to prepare RE alloy nanomaterials. (2) RE elements have a very high affinity with oxygen and can generate stable oxides when they are in contact with water, oxygen, and other substances [10]. At present, there are three main methods for preparing RE alloy nanomaterials: the solvothermal method, the calcination method, and the electrochemical deposition method. In this paper, the preparation methods of common RE alloy nanomaterials are reviewed, and studies are conducted on RE alloy nanomaterials for electrocatalysis, including hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), ORR, methanol oxidation reaction (MOR), ethanol oxidation reaction (EOR), and other catalytic reactions. By summarizing the progress of RE alloy nanomaterials in electrocatalytic reactions, the future development trend and problems are provided (Scheme 1 ). 2 Synthesis 2.1 Solvothermal method Solvothermal processing is a new process developed from hydrothermal processing that is completed in a closed system (such as Teflon flasks) in a high temperature and high pressure organic solvent. This method is considered an ideal choice for the preparation of ordered metal nanocrystals with controllable size and morphology [11–13]. In general, while the response temperature is higher than the boiling point or higher pressure, the physical and chemical properties of water and non-water media (such as viscosity, solubility, and dissociation constant) will change significantly, resulting in an increase in the activity of the reaction and the input of external energy. Therefore, the solution thermal method provides a potential solution to overcome the high energy barrier and realize the transition from disorder to order. The hydrothermal and solvothermal methods are similar; the only difference is the use of the aqueous solution in hydrothermal and nonaqueous solution in the solvothermal method during the alloy growth procedure. They are simple and facile in operation but performed in conditions above ambient temperature and pressures. The solvothermal approaches are relatively environmentally benign, consume low energy, and performed in a liquid environment to synthesize the materials with the required morphology and controlled size. Apart from this, the method is employed with higher pressure and minimum loss of nanomaterials, and the procedure is well controlled through liquid-phase or multiphase chemical reactions. On the other hand, these methods have disadvantages because the high temperature, pressure, corrosive resistance, and high-cost materials are required. The determination of the exact reaction equilibria is also difficult due to the presence of numerous species in the nucleation and growth steps [14]. Kim et al. prepared RE nanoalloys in a hydrogen atmosphere using ethylene glycol as a reducing agent, including Pd4IrSc0.1/C, Pd4IrY0.1/C, Pd4IrLa0.1/C, Pd4IrSc0.5/C, Pd4IrY0.5/C, and Pd4IrLa0.5/C [15]. It was found that the catalyst was widely distributed, and the size of the catalyst particles was larger than the crystal size on the carbon support (larger than 7 nm), indicating the formation of polycrystalline particles. Zheng et al. modified platinum-based catalysts with Sn and Eu and found that the introduction of Sn and Eu makes C–C bond breakage more likely, thus enhancing the ethanol oxidation performance of the catalyst [16]. The catalyst nanoparticles were widely distributed on the carbon carrier, and the mean particle size of the Pt3Sn1/C catalyst is 3.8 nm; similarly, the mean particle size of the Pt3Sn1Eu1/C catalyst is 3.6 nm. Numan et al. prepared the mesoporous zeolite by the solvothermal method and then placed Pt-Ce intermetallic nanoparticles in the zeolite by the impregnation reduction strategy [17]. The metal nanoparticles are widely distributed in mesoporous molecular sieve carriers, and the average diameter is about 1.4 nm. The catalytic oxidation of ethane using CO2 as a soft oxidant could facilitate the utilization of CO2 and ethane from the shale gas as a raw material to produce value-added ethylene via a dehydrogenation process. This supported catalyst was highly stable and selective for ethylene production compared to supported platinum. Hu et al. prepared Pt x RE nanoalloys with adjustable alloy composition and particle size by the general synthesis route [18]. Metal ions are embedded in the C-N network and then deposited on the carbon carrier to prevent the formation of oxides. Platinum- RE nano-cube material (Pt-RE-NC) was prepared by mixing precious metal salt with a carbon carrier in g-C3N4. The C-N network structure of Pt-RE-NC was completely dissociated by high-temperature heat treatment, and the metal ions in it could be effectively removed. On this basis, Pt is reduced to metal particles in hydrogen, while RE is converted to crystals on diamides. RE2(CN2)3 was reduced to Pt-RE nanoalloy in the H2 atmosphere. RE2(CN2)3 is widely distributed on the surface of Pt nanoparticles and is in close contact with Pt nanoparticles. At high temperatures, excess RE2(CN2)3 is slowly oxidized into RE metal oxides, which are finally removed by acid leaching (Fig. 1 a and b). After acid leaching, Pt-RE particles have a porous structure, and the mean diameter of the alloy particles is 8.5 nm. Kanady et al. synthesized Pt3Y intermetallic nanoparticles by annealing molten salts of alkali metal triethyl-borohydride, PtCl4, and YCl3 at high temperatures [19]. In the synthesis process, it is not necessary to add organic ligands as stabilizers, and the as-synthesized Pt3Y nanoparticles can be shifted from the salt “solvent” to the carbon carrier, which facilitated the preparation of electrode materials (Fig. 1c). Pt3Y nanoparticles were prepared; the alloy particles range in diameter from 5 to 20 nm. The method is also applicable when synthesizing other intermetallic compounds (Pt3Sc, Pt3Lu, Pt2Na, and Au2Y). The solvothermal synthesis of RE alloy nanomaterials has high purity and narrow particle size distribution, which has great advantages in the preparation of nanomaterials. However, due to the particularity of reaction conditions, the reaction process is difficult to control, the phenomenon is difficult to observe, and the safety is poor, which are great challenges. Therefore, in the process of reaction, the reaction temperature and time should be strictly controlled. 2.2 Calcination method The calcination method is a simple and scalable method for synthesizing RE alloy nanomaterials. Qin et al. conducted heat treatment of the Pt-Ce nanoalloy and investigated its application in electrocatalytic reactions [20]. The results show that the Pt-Ce alloy catalyst particles have different diameters and wider particle size distributions under different reduction temperatures. At 600 °C, the diameter of Pt-Ce alloy catalyst particles ranges from about 4.5 to 9.5 nm. When the reduction temperature reaches 800 °C, the diameter of Pt-Ce alloy catalyst particles varies from about 6.5 to 13.5 nm (Fig. 2 a–d). By doping Pt and RE, the dealloying can be effectively prevented, and the ORR activity can be improved. Pt-RE alloy nanostructures prepared by the calcination process are promising materials for ORR electrocatalysts, although further research is needed to improve their stability. The calcination process can be combined with other methods to synthesize RE alloy nanomaterials. Campos-Roldán et al. prepared a series of Pt x Gd/C type catalysts using carbonized diimide as the raw material, followed by high temperature treatment [21]. The different proportions of Pt and Gd added will have different effects on the crystal structure, diameter, and specific surface chemical properties and then change the ORR activity. Additionally, with the increase in Gd content, the morphology of Gd was transformed from solid nanoparticle to porous, and the critical particle size was about 10 nm. Gunji et al. prepared an atomically ordered intermetallic Pt5La nanoparticle using the chemical process followed by calcination, and the effect of the roasting process on the microstructure of RE alloys was studied [22]. The crystal pattern of Pt-La nanocrystals is dependent on the forging temperature, forming face-centered cubic (disordered) structure below 700 °C and CaCu5 (ordered) structure at 800 °C (Fig. 2e). Pt5La nanoparticles (NPs) have a high Z-shaped crystal surface with a stepped structure, which helps to improve the performance of ORR. During the calcination process, the temperature and the time can have a huge impact on the final product. A small amount of La2O3 was formed during the preparation process, which was removed in the acidic condition. Wu et al. prepared a Pt-Pr alloy catalyst, studied its ORR properties, and compared it with a Pt/C catalyst [23]. It is found that the ORR performance of Pt-Pr alloy catalyst is better, obviously. And the improvement was achieved through the calcination treatment of Pt-Pr alloy after using polyols as raw materials (Fig. 2f). The Pt-Pr/Pr6O11 composite was obtained by sticking Pr6O11 nanoparticles on the surface of Pt-Pr alloy, and the average diameter of the composite was about 2–4 nm. The lanthanide platinum intermetallic compounds can be obtained by reducing cyanide with hydrogen heat treatment, and the nanocrystals are deposited on supports with stable and large surface area (such as porous carbon, porous oxide/carbon composites, etc.), which can effectively alleviate the agglomeration of nanocrystals during high-temperature heat treatment. Roy et al. used the YCl3 treatment to heat treat Pt/C nanoparticles in a hydrogen atmosphere and expanded the preparation of intermetallic alloys with Pt x Y nanoparticles attached to carbon support [24]. Thus, the diameter of the Pt x Y/C catalyst is widely distributed (about 9.9 ± 3.6 nm). When the doping ratio of YCl3 to Pt/C is 1:1.5, the selectivity and restriction effect of the chloride precursor are the best. The thermal synthesis method can effectively regulate the alloy phase, and the use of this method can be extended to other RE elements. Lux et al. used low concentrations of hydrogen to anneal Ln[Pt(CN)6]2 at 1000 °C to prepare PrPt2 and CePt2 nanoparticles [25]; the average particle size of the catalyst is about 25 nm, and the specific surface area is about 15 m2 g−1. Schwämmlein et al. prepared the synthesis of bimetallic Pt x Y/C nanomaterials by impregnating the commercial Pt/C by using yttrium halide as a precursor and then heat treating in hydrogen, and the particle size was 10 nm [26]. Because the reduction of commonly used Pt precursors is very simple and occurs at much lower temperatures than Y formed by YCl3, Pt x Y/C was synthesized. Itahara et al. obtained the carbon-supported Pt-RE nanoparticles using RE chloride as the raw material after heat treatment under 4% hydrogen gas [27]. The mean size of Pt-Ce nanoparticles was 5.5 nm. Fan et al. used Pt/C@g-C3N4 to prepare Pt5La nanoalloy in a hydrogen atmosphere at different temperatures [28], and the formation temperature of the Pt5La nanoalloy is 560 °C, and it has a high alloying degree at 700 °C. Its mean particle diameter is 7.8 nm. Zhu et al. developed a simple method to synthesize Pt5La intermetallic compounds, and the as-synthesized La-metal organic framework (La-MOF) was composed of groups of ligands linked to La oxides in an orderly manner [29]. The La-MOF was then carbonized at high temperature for in-situ adsorption of the Pt precursor to be introduced. The particle is around 7 nm in size and widely distributed. There is strong electron interaction between Pt and La, and the obtained Pt5La alloy catalyst shows high catalytic activity. Ryoo et al. used the mesoporous zeolite as the carrier, and Pt and RE metal precursors, which were reduced under high temperature in a hydrogen atmosphere, were added to the mesoporous zeolite [30]. The bimetallic Pt and Y nanoparticles obtained by loading on mesoporous zeolite are intermetallic compounds, and the silanol nests in mesoporous zeolites can effectively activate hard-to-reduce RE elements (i.e., RE elements with low reduction potentials). The silanol nests can make REE exist in the form of a single atom and have a higher chemical potential than bulk oxide, so they can cross the energy barrier and form alloy nanoparticles. The metal nanoparticles of about 3 nm were dispersed uniformly on the zeolite carrier. The RE alloy nanomaterial synthesized by calcination method has high utilization rate and low use cost, which is suitable for large-scale production. However, due to the particularity of reaction conditions, the composition is not uniform, the particles are easy to agglomerate, and the diameter distribution is wide, which are great challenges. 2.3 Electrodeposition method Under the action of an external electric field, electrodeposition is also an effective method to synthesize RE alloys by combining RE ions with transition or precious metal ions on the cathode surface. Like chemical reduction, the electrolyte solution used for electrodeposition must have a wide electrochemical window because of the low reduction potential of RE metals, and molten salt or ionic liquid is ideal electrolytes for the electrodeposition method. There are two methods to produce RE alloys by molten salt electrodeposition: co-deposition and non-co-deposition. In co-deposition, RE and other metal ions are simultaneously reduced to the cathode. In non-co-deposition, RE ions or other metals are reduced on the electrode and react with the metal on the electrode to form a new alloy. In comparison with the non-co-deposition method, the co-deposition method can more easily control the morphology and properties of RE alloys. Because lanthanum and cerium are relatively rich among RE elements in natural ores, Sahoo et al. studied the production of lanthanum and cerium alloys through a single carrier electrolyte [31]. Lanthanum oxide and cerium oxide were dissolved in sodium chloride, potassium chloride, etc., and continuously stirred, which was then dehydrated and mixed with LiCl-KCl in different proportions as an electrolyte for lanthanum electrodeposition. Han et al. synthesized Mg-Li-Al-La tetra-metallic RE alloy by the electrodeposition method under the condition of molten LiCl-KCl at 580 °C [32]. The AlCl3 or AlF3 promoted the deposition of La on the active matrix, providing a quiet environment for the continuous preparation of tetra-metallic RE alloys, and the lanthanum existed mainly in the form of Al2La in tetra-metallic RE alloys. Ionic liquid is also an ideal electrolyte for the electrodeposition method for RE alloy nanomaterials. Gong et al. synthesized the ternary alloy nanoparticles of Pt-Sm-Co using a two-step method [33]. Firstly, Sm-Co nanoparticles were prepared by the potentiostatic electrochemical deposition in an ionic liquid, and then Sm-Co nanoparticles were replaced with K2PtCl4 to obtain ternary alloy nanoparticles of Pt-Sm-Co grown on Sm-Co nanoparticles. Li et al. obtained the Ce-Co alloy by the electrodeposition method [34]. For the potentiostatic electrodeposition, the Ce-Co alloy showed a film of 2 μm thickness and a smooth surface. The size of the alloy film prepared by electrostatic electrodeposition is larger than that prepared by cyclic electrodeposition, and the films prepared by both methods have a metallic luster. However, compared with the cyclic electrodeposition method, the strength of Ce-Co alloy films obtained by the constant voltage method is higher, and the surface is smoother and more uniform. Wei et al. synthesized the Sm-Co alloy by using the direct current aqueous electrodeposition method [35], and the Sm-Co nanoparticles showed a nodular surface. The Sm-Co alloy diameters ranged from 1.5 to 2.5 μm. Gao et al. prepared a Ni-La alloy thin film by electrochemical deposition, in which n-butyl-n-methylpyridine-dicyandiamide ionic liquid was used as an electrolyte solution [36]. The results indicate that electrodeposition promotes the preparation of Ni-La alloy. The deposition of alloy was grown uniformly on the Cu substrate, and the Ni-La alloy film was composed of a lot of rough and connecting nanoparticles. Xu et al. obtained the Nd-Fe alloy by the electrodeposition method in the electrolyte of 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium dicyanamide ([EMIM][DCA]), and the Nd-Fe alloy had a sphere structure with a porous nanocrystalline structure [37]. Liu et al. doped Ho into Pt-Ru/C by pulsed electrodeposition to obtain a Pt-Ru-Ho/C alloy catalyst that can be used in the electrooxidation process of methanol [38], and the electrolyte was composed of sulfuric acid, sodium acid, oxalic acid, and boric acid. With the increase of Ho content, the diameter of alloy particles decreases, and the Ru-Ho0.2/C alloy showed superior ability in the methanol electrooxidation. Schwartz et al. obtained the binary iron group (IG)-RE and ternary IG-RE-B alloys [39]. RE (Ce, Nd, Sm, and Gd) alloys were prepared by the direct current and pulse electrodeposition method, resulting in nanocrystalline deposits (grain size, 5 nm). Li et al. prepared a Pr-Mg-Co ternary alloy film by potentiostatic electrolysis under the action of urea and choline chloride ionic liquid; the size of the Pr-Mg-Co alloy film was about 744–844 nm [40]. With the help of co-electrodeposition, Madram et al. synthesized Ni-P-La alloy electrocatalysts [41], and the surface of the Ni-P-La alloy was rough and porous. RE alloy nanomaterials synthesized by electrodeposition have unique properties, simple synthesis method, and low use cost, providing a practical solution for industrial production. However, despite the advantages of electrodeposition technology in terms of energy, it still faces many challenges: uneven distribution and small nanoparticle size. But these problems can be solved by changing one or all the parameters, such as deposition potential time and electrolyte composition, by which the particle size and density can be controlled. 2.4 Other synthetic method 2.4.1 Dealloying method Alloying is a top-down method that can be used to prepare porous metals or alloys with nanoscale pores and skeletons. The connected skeleton structure facilitates electron transport, and the connected holes facilitate full contact between the electrolyte and the catalyst. By dealloying the mechanically alloyed Al-Cu-Pd-Pt precursor, Sun et al. prepared the four-element nano-porous Pt-Pd-Cu-Al alloy [42]. The average diameter of the ligament is 2.6–0.6 nm. This hierarchical porous structure was beneficial for improving structural stability and electrocatalytic activity. By dealloying the Pt-Y-Al ternary alloy with a chemical method, Cui et al. obtained Pt-Y alloy with a nanopore structure [43]. The Pt-Y alloy with nanopore structure was obtained by dealloying Pt15Y5Al80 powder in a sodium hydroxide solution under N2 conditions. The de-alloyed powder maintained the particle shape of the precursor, and at the same time, the nano-porous morphology was clearly observed inside the particles. The mean ligament size of the alloy is 5 nm. Dealloying method has unique advantages in the preparation of nanomaterials: flexible preparation method and wide application range; by adjusting alloy composition and corrosion conditions, nanomaterials with different structures, shapes, and scales can be obtained, which can well meet the requirements of preparing open-structure electrode materials. There is no organic solvent involved in the preparation process, and it can be combined with electrochemical, chemical vapor deposition, and other technologies. The obtained nanomaterials have high surface cleanliness, easy composite between materials, and easy to establish a bridge between electrode material structure and electrochemical reaction mechanism. Based on mature dealloying technology, functional modification and chemical induction were carried out, combined with chemical vapor deposition to change the annealing conditions, and further regulate the structure of electrode materials. Nanomaterials are small and can give full play to their dynamic advantages. Porous micron materials can improve the compaction density and avoid agglomeration and pulverization. Therefore, porous micro-nano structural materials have the advantages of high specific surface, short diffusion free path, and buffer volume expansion, which is conducive to the development of electrode materials with high specific capacity and long cycle. But dealloying method limits the application of template method. 2.4.2 Chemical vapor deposition method Chemical vapor deposition (CVD) is a process by which a gaseous or gaseous substance reacts to form a solid deposit at the gaseous phase or gas-solid interface. It is a method by which gaseous or membrane-containing substances react chemically on the substrate surface to produce a thin film. Zhou et al. prepared large-area SmB6 nanowires on Au-coated silicon wafers by using SmCl3 and BCl3 as source materials by the CVD method [44]. The diameter of the growing SmB6 nanowires was 60–150 nm, and the length was 1–5 μm. Gan et al. prepared a wide range of LaB6 nanowires on a nickel-plated Si wafer by using B, B2O3, and LaCl3 powders by low-pressure CVD in a tube furnace (Fig. 3 a) [45]. The nanowire has an inclination angle of 50°–80° with the substrate, showing a uniform morphology; its surface is very smooth; and its distribution on the substrate is also very uniform. Nanowires are about 100 nm in diameter and tens of microns in length. Gan et al. used B, B2O3, and SmCl3 as raw materials to prepare SmB6 nanoribbons and nanowires in a low-pressure tube furnace by the solid synthesis method (Fig. 3b) [46]. SmB6 nanoribbons and nanowires were prepared on Si (1 0 0) wafers using 10 nm Ni film as substrate to form SmB6 nanostructures. The average length of the nanoribbon is 130 μm, the average width is a few microns, and the thickness varies from 40 to 500 nm. Nanoribbons generally have two typical forms: sword and boomerang nanoribbons, and most sword and boomerang nanoribbons have smooth edges. Fu et al. synthesized the CeB6 nanowire arrays on gold-plated flexible carbon cloth by low-pressure CVD, and the source materials were CeCl3 and B2H6. At the upstream end of the quartz tube, a clean carbon cloth deposited with gold film by electron beam evaporation was used as a substrate, on which an array of CeB6 nanowires was grown [47]. The large-scale, three-dimensional (3D) CeB6 nanostructure arrays were formed on the carbon cloth substrate surface. CeB6 nanowires with 80–200 nm width and 5–30 mm length were prepared. CVD is a kind of chemical technology, which mainly uses one or several gaseous compounds or elements containing thin film elements to produce thin film by chemical reaction on the surface of substrate. CVD is a new technology developed in recent decades to prepare inorganic materials. CVD has been widely used to purify substances, develop new crystals, and deposit various monocrystalline, polycrystalline or glassy inorganic film materials. These materials may be oxides, sulfides, nitrides, carbides, or binary or polyelemental interelemental compounds in groups II-V, II-IV, IV-VI, and their physical functions can be precisely controlled by gas-doped deposition processes. CVD has become a new field in inorganic synthetic chemistry. Modern science and technology need to use a large number of new inorganic materials with different functions. These functional materials must be high purity, or doping materials formed by deliberately adding some impurity into high purity materials. However, many preparation methods we are familiar with in the past, such as high temperature melting, precipitation and crystallization in aqueous solution, are often difficult to meet these requirements, and it is difficult to guarantee the high purity of the product. At present, CVD technology has been widely used in many aspects such as protective film layer, microelectronics technology, solar energy utilization, optical fiber communication, superconductivity technology, the preparation of new materials and so on. With the continuous improvement of industrial production requirements, CVD process and equipment have been improved, not only using a variety of new heating sources, but also making full use of plasma, laser, electron beam, and other auxiliary methods to reduce the reaction temperature, so that its application range is broader. The CVD should be developed to reduce harmful products and increase the scale of industrial production. In addition, to make the deposition temperature of CVD more low, to control the CVD process more accurately, to develop thick film deposition technology, new film materials and new material synthesis technology will become the main research topics in the future. 2.4.3 Magnetron sputtering method Magnetron sputtering is a commonly used physical vapor deposition (PVD) method, which has many advantages such as low deposition temperature, fast deposition speed, good uniformity of deposited films, and a composition close to the target material composition. Hernandez-Fernandez et al. developed a single-target co-sputtering Pt-Y alloy thin film synthesis method to synthesize a series of thin films with different proportions and thicknesses on the platinum sputtering target surface [48]. Pt x Y alloy film is formed on a glassy carbon substrate by direct current magnetron sputtering with a composite target. Its thickness is 60 nm, and its diameter is 3 cm. Magnetron sputtering method can prepare RE alloy materials with fast deposition speed. For most materials, if they can be made into harrow, sputtering can be realized, with good repeatability and easy industrialization. However, since magnetron sputtering requires magnetic field, in order to avoid damaging the machine, materials with ferromagnetism cannot be synthesized by this method. The circular magnetic field used by magnetron sputtering forces the secondary electrons to jump around the circular magnetic field. Accordingly, the region controlled by the annular magnetic field is the region with the highest plasma density. During magnetron sputtering, argon, the sputtering gas, can be seen to emit a strong light blue glow at this position, forming a halo. The target under the ring is the most heavily bombarded by ions, sputtering a ring of grooves. The annular magnetic field is the orbit of the electron, which is represented by the glow and groove of the ring. Once the sputtering trench of magnetron sputtering target penetrates the target, it will lead to the scrap of the whole target, so the utilization rate of the target is not high, generally less than 40%, and the plasma is unstable, can not realize the low temperature and high speed sputtering of strong magnetic materials, because almost all the magnetic flux can not pass the magnetic target, so the magnetic field can not be strengthened near the target surface. 2.4.4 Sol-gel method Sol-gel method is a common method to prepare nanomaterials. It forms gel slurry by mixing water-based organic and inorganic materials in water, which is then extracted, dried, concentrated, recycled, and cooled to form tiny aggregates of the required size. RE doped materials with unique electronic ground state configurations are considered as emerging alternatives to conventional Pt/C for ORR. Li et al. investigated gadolinium (Gd)-induced valence structure engineering for enhancing oxygen electrocatalysis [49]. The Gd2O3-Co heterostructure loaded on N-doped graphene (Gd2O3-Co/NG) is constructed as the target catalyst via a facile sol-gel assisted strategy. This synthetic strategy allows Gd2O3-Co nanoparticles to distribute uniformly on an N-graphene surface and form intimate Gd2O3/Co interface sites (Fig. 4 a–c). The Gd2O3-Co/NG presents a 3D porous network structure composed of the crosslinked plicate nanosheets. Because of unique 3D network, Gd2O3-Co/NG displays a high Brunauer-Emmett-Teller specific surface area of around 177.1 m2 g−1. The 3D porous architecture together with high specific surface area would expose more accessible active-sites and facilitate the electron/mass transfer capability in electrocatalysis. The result reflects that the Gd2O3-Co nanoparticles with uniform distribution are well dispersed on the NG nanosheets without obvious aggregation, showing a narrow size-distribution and a small average particle-size of 11.2 nm. 3D porous network would be effective in confining the grain growth and agglomeration of nanoparticles. It is demonstrated that the incorporation of Gd2O3 into metallic Co can dramatically enhance its electrocatalytic performance for the ORR. This method has the advantages of low cost, easy implementation, and mass production. However, there are also some shortcomings, such as high requirements for raw material compatibility, complex and time-consuming production process, and difficult characterization, and distribution evaluation of the obtained micro-sized aggregates. 3 RE alloy in electrocatalysis 3.1 Oxygen reduction reaction ORR holds a special place in the fields of energy conversion application and fundamental electrochemistry. For practical applications, the ORR is involved into fuel cells and metal-air batteries as the cathodic reaction [50]. Among all metal elements, platinum has the best catalytic performance for the ORR reaction. But its high price limits its commercialization in fuel cells. In Pt and RE alloys, the adsorption energy between Pt and oxygen can be effectively controlled through the electron interaction between RE and Pt. In addition, the RE-doped Pt alloy has an abnormally negative enthalpy of formation, which improves the mechanical stability of the catalyst and prevents dealloying during the reaction. Malacrida et al. prepared three different RE doped Pt-based alloys (Pt5La, Pt5Ce, and Pt5Gd) and studied their ORR properties [51]. During the reaction, the alloy surface was composed of a layer of Pt atoms about 1 nm thickness, and the activity was regulated by the strain effect in the Pt atom layer. At the same time, the layer also plays a role in stabilizing the alloy particles and preventing them from being further oxidized and dissolved under electrochemical conditions. Jiang et al. obtained Pt x Y/C nanoparticles by one-step molten salt synthesis in order to evaluate the electrocatalytic performance of the catalyst on ORR [52]. The ORR properties of Pt x Y/C, Pt2Gd/C, Pt2La/C, and Pt/C catalysts and their polarization curves were measured in 0.1 M HClO4 electrolyte saturated with oxygen (Fig. 5 a), and they all have higher half-wave voltages than Pt/C. The half-wave voltage of Pt x Y/C is 0.905 V, which is the highest among the prepared catalysts and 25 mV higher than the half-wave voltage of Pt/C (0.88 V). And the kinetic current densities for Pt5Ce and Pt5La at 0.90 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) are 7.4 ± 0.4 and 6.8 ± 0.3 mA cm−2, respectively. The mass activities at 0.9 V (vs. RHE) of Pt x Y/C, Pt2Gd/C, and Pt2La/C are 0.3, 0.25, and 0.17 A mgPt −1, which are 2.5 times, 2.08 times, and 1.42 times as much as commercial Pt/C catalysts (0.12 A mgPt −1), respectively. This corroborates the ORR activity enhancement of Pt-RE metal alloy catalysts (Fig. 5b). Yoo et al. found that due to the synergistic action between Pt and RE atoms, the center of the Pt d band moves downward, which reduces the adsorption capacity of oxygen-containing components (*O, *OH, *OOH) and thus improves the catalytic performance [53]. To investigate and compare the catalytic activities of the ORRs of the Pt3La alloy and pure Pt electrodes, they conducted hydrodynamic measurements in an O2-saturated 0.1 M HClO4 solution. The activity of the Pt3La catalyst, expressed as kinetic current density (j k) at 0.9 V, was much higher than that of pure Pt. The extremely high specific activity of the Pt3La catalyst is 7.3 mA cm−2 (real) at 0.9 V. At the same time, the larger atomic radius of RE is used to generate compressive strain on the particle surface of the alloy, which reduces the adsorption of active intermediate species on the Pt site and regulates the binding energy of oxygen-containing intermediate species. Using the Pt-RE alloy as a catalyst can not only enhance the performance of ORR but also reduce the load on Pt. Johansson et al. prepared the microstructural polycrystalline Pt3Sc at extremely high vacuum temperatures [54]. A layer of Pt coating was formed on the surface of Pt3Sc by ultra-high vacuum heat treatment. The thermal desorption of CO was used to study the reactivity of the coating. Pt3Sc showed good electrochemical properties in ORR. Hernandez-Fernandez et al. synthesized Pt x Y alloy nanoparticles under ultra-high vacuum conditions [48]. In the same size of pure platinum, all Pt x Y showed significant improvements in specific activity except for very small nanoparticles (4 nm). It was found that the larger the diameter of Pt x Y particles, the stronger the specific activity, which is consistent with results of a pure Pt catalyst, while the activity of larger particles converged on the polycrystalline plane. Pure platinum shows peak mass activity at 3 nm, and its particle size needs to be improved to improve its stability. The mass activity was the highest at 3.05 A mgPt −1 (diameter 9 nm, 0.9 V). In order to provide microscopic understanding of the reaction, density functional calculations (DFT) calculations were performed. The surface reactivity of the different polycrystalline alloys was tested in ultra-high vacuum by CO temperature programmed desorption (CO TPD). The main interest of these alloys is, however, for the oxygen reduction reaction, which has oxygenated species as intermediates (*O, *HO and *HOO). A relevant question is therefore if it is possible to relate the binding energy of *OC to that of the oxygen species in the oxygen reduction reaction. When considering different pure metals their *OC and *HO binding energies do not scale. For the Pt overlayers on top of Pt3M alloys such a relation could, however, still be possible. The result shows the calculated *OC, *HO, and *HOO binding energies on three different atop sites (“0”, “1”, and “2”) of Pt overlayer structures on Pt3Sc and Pt3Y with subsurface solute metal concentrations of 25% and 50%. Although it is not perfectly linear, a clear trend is observed. A surface which binds *OC weakly will also bind *HO and *HOO weakly. Two datapoints (“Pt3Y 50% 2” and “Pt3Sc 50% 2”) on the *HO versus *OC binding energy graph are outliers and it is noted that they are also outliers when comparing the *HO and *HOO binding energies which should scale linearly. A linear fit is made to the data (except the two outliers) giving the following relations. (1) ΔE bin,OH = (0.42 ± 0.04) × ΔE bin,CO (2) ΔE bin,OOH = (0.48 ± 0.05) × ΔE bin,CO The ideal ORR catalyst should bind oxygen around 0.2 eV weaker than Pt. From the scaling relations between *O and *HO this corresponds to binding *HO 0.1 eV weaker. From Eq. (1) this is seen to correspond to a weaker binding of *OC by 0.1 e V 0.24 = 10:24 eV. They have plotted the calculated CO adsorption energies and activation energies for desorption on different Pd nanostructures versus the corresponding desorption temperatures. They found that there is a linear relation between the two, which can be expressed as. (3) ΔE bin,CO = 0.0028 × ΔT des,CO From Eq. (3), we get that a decrease of *OC binding by 0.24 eV corresponds to a lowering in desorption temperature of CO by 0.24 e V 0.0028 e V K - 1 = 85 K. There is clearly some uncertainty on this value, but the key thing to remember is that a Pt overlayer catalyst has to bind CO less strongly (on the order of 85 K) in order to have the best possible bonding of the O species necessary for the ORR. A similar technique was used by Zamburlini et al. to prepare Pt x Gd alloy nanoparticles [55]. The results showed that the catalytic performance of Pt5Gd film was 4.5 times higher than that of pure polycrystalline Pt, and the catalytic performance reached 9.0 ± 0.6 mA cm−2, which was 2.5 times higher than that of Pt film. However, the catalytic performance of Pt5Gd alloy remained about 80% after stability tests in O2-saturated HClO4 (0.60–1.00 V vs. RHE) environments. The overall activity of Pt5Gd film is almost five times higher than that of polycrystalline Pt. Lindahl et al. prepared Pt-Y alloy catalysts with different components (Pt2Y, Pt3Y, and Pt5Y) by single target co-sputtering, and their thickness was approximately 1.5–50 nm [56]. The results show that the alloy film has high ORR activity and good stability. The specific activity of 27-nm Pt3Y film is 13.4 ± 0.4 mA cm−2, that is, its specific activity is 7 times that of polycrystalline Pt (bulk). After 10,000 cycles of stabilization, 80% of the activity was unchanged. The specific activity for the ORR, measured at 0.9 V vs. RHE and normalized with the electrochemical surface area (ECSA) obtained from CO stripping, is 13.4 ± 0.4 mA cm−2. This is a seven times enhancement compared to Pt(bulk). Escudero-Escribano et al. studied that Pt5La, Pt5Ce, Pt5Dy, Pt5Tm, and Pt5Gd Pt-RE ORR performance was three to six times more than Pt/C catalyst, and was two times more than Pt3Co and Pt3Ni catalyst [57]. Among the investigated metal alloys, the activity of Pt5Tb is the highest, followed by Pt5Gd (activity coefficient between 3 and 6), which has a volcanic trend, of which Pt5Tb and Pt5Gd account for the maximum. When the particle size of a RE alloy decreases, the stability of the Pt-RE alloy will also decrease. The bond energy of Pt5Dy and Pt5Tm are too weak with OH; that of Pt5Gd, Pt5Sm, Pt5Ce, and Pt5La are too strong; and Pt5Tb occupies the best binding energy. At 0.9 V, Pt5Tb is the most active polycrystalline Pt-based catalyst reported. All the materials exhibited activity enhancement by a factor of 3 to 6 over pure Pt. By solid-state synthesis, Brandiele et al. studied Pt-Y alloy nanoparticles, in which the alloy content accounted for 41% of the nanoparticles [58], and the mesoporous carbons were disseminated in acetone along with metallic Pt and Y precursors. The half-wave potential of Pt-Y alloy nanoparticles was greater than that of commercial Pt/C and had 1.3 times more mass activity. It can be seen that Pt x Y shows a remarkably high electrocatalytic activity towards ORR since the half-wave potential was 0.891 V vs. RHE and largely higher than the Pt/C standard obtained in the same experimental condition (0.824 V vs. RHE). Xiang et al. studied a novel electrochemical method to develop Pt-La alloy nanoparticles used for EOR reactions [59]. The Pt-La alloy nanoparticles are concave with a size of about 47 nm, and the size is relatively uniform. This has been well established because of the obvious benefits of the alloy effect; therefore, at kink and edge sites, the Pt-La alloy nanoparticles exhibited significant activity. By dealloying a ternary Pt-Y-Al, a poreless Pt-Y alloy was prepared by Cui et al [43]. The obvious compression strain of the Pt-Y alloy reduces the binding capacity of ORR intermediates and thus reduces the number of electrons transferred from Y to Pt. The d orbital of Pt is filled with this additional electron transfer, thereby reducing the d band center of Pt, which has a favorable effect on ORR dynamics. NP-Pt-Y has a specific kinetic current of 1.94 mA cm−2Pt at 0.9 V, and its specific surface area is 10.8 times that of the Pt/C catalyst (0.18 mA cm−2) and 3.2 times that of NP-Pt (0.61 mA cm−2). In addition, the mass activity of NP-Pt-Y (1.03 A mg−1) was 8.6 times higher than that of Pt/C (0.12 A mg−1) and 3.7 times higher than that of NP-Pt (0.28 A mg−1). To sum up, the ORR performance of Pt-Y is higher than that of Pt nanoparticles and Pt/C catalyst. Using Pt and Y as raw materials in anhydrous ethanol, Han et al. formed a poreless structure of Pt-Y on the Pt (1 1 1) crystal plane after electrodeposition for 1500 s [60]. Because Pt-Y alloy nanoparticles are nonporous, their roughness coefficient is 10 times that of Pt/C, and the initial ORR potential of Pt-Y alloy nanoparticles is higher than that of Pt/C. Fichtner et al. recently proposed a “top-down“ preparation technique for Pt-Pr/C composite catalysts [61]. Pt-lanthanide alloys have strained and highly defective structures, which can significantly enhance their ORR properties in acidic environments. Relative to RHE, the activity of the Pt x Pr/C catalyst increases by 3.5 times, and its mass activity increases by 1.7 times compared with the commercially available Pt/C catalyst at a voltage of 0.9 V. Pt x Pr/C showed ∼3.5 times higher specific activity (1.96 mA cmPt −2 at 0.9 V vs. RHE) compared to commercial Pt/C catalyst (0.61 mA cmPt −2 at 0.9 V vs. RHE) (Fig. 5c and d). Pd has a similar electronic structure to Pt but is more than 50 times more naturally present. Therefore, Pd alloys will be an effective way to develop non-Pt catalysts with similar catalytic properties to Pt. Under acidic conditions, pure Pd is more active than any other precious metal except Pt. However, ORR activity is lower than that of commercial Pt/C catalysts due to its poor stability and solubility in acidic media [62]. As a fuel cell catalyst, Greeley et al. found that the activity enhancement of Pt3Sc and Pt3Y over Pt is plotted as a function of potential. At 0.9 V, Pt3Sc shows a 50% increase in specific activity over Pt, and Pt3Y shows an improvement by a factor of six. At 0.87 V, Pt3Sc shows an 80% increase in activity whereas the activity of Pt3Y is enhanced by an order of magnitude. Owing to the steep gradient (or Tafel slope) of the polarization curve for Pt3Y, the activity improvement over Pt should be even more pronounced at potentials below 0.87 V. And the Pt3Y electrode shows the highest ORR activity measured under these conditions for any bulk, polycrystalline metallic surface. The activity of our Pt3Y sample is closer to that of single-crystal Pt3Ni(1 1 1) than to polycrystalline Pt3Ni, which is not quite as active [63]. Lee et al. prepared Pd3/Y-based ORR electrocatalytic materials by impregnating Pd into Y and doping it into active carbon nanofibers (ACNF) [64]. The electrochemical characteristics of Pd3/Y-CNF and Pd3/Y-ACNF were investigated in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous electrolyte, the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves confirm that the electrochemically accessible surface area for Pd3/Y-ACNF is larger than that for Pd3/Y-CNF and commercial Pt/C (Fig. 6 a). The initial voltage of Pd3/Y-ANCF catalyst is about 0.90 V, and the half-wave voltage is about 0.81 V, which is close to the starting voltage (0.92 V) and half-wave voltage (0.81 V) of commercial Pt/C catalyst. The appropriate alloying between Pd and Y was formed to improve its electrochemical performance (Fig. 6b). Brandiele et al. prepared Pd3Y particles as ORR electrocatalysts using laser-assisted synthesis techniques [65]. The catalytic d-band center model of this Pd-based catalyst is also consistent with that of Pt-based ORR catalysts, in which the electron structure of the surface Pt is changed by the strain effect of the alloying element M or the electronic interaction of Pt-M (i.e., ligand effect). When the metal surface experiences a compressive or tensile strain, the overlap of the d-bands will increase or decrease, thus changing the bandwidth of d and the adsorption energy between the alloy and oxygen [66]. The higher the center of the d band is, the closer it is to the Fermi level, the more the anti-bonding orbital after bonding with the adsorption orbital is above the Fermi level, the lower the probability of an electron filling in the anti-bonding orbital, and therefore the more stable the adsorption and the stronger the adsorption energy, which is different from that of pure Pt [67]. Brandiele et al. found that in the crystal structure of Pd introduced by Y, Y has a strong coordination effect with Pd, resulting in negative migration of the d-band center of Pd and higher catalytic activity than non-alloying Pd [58]. The PdY NPs were tested in an O2-saturated 0.1 M H2SO4 solution and the results shows the typical CV features as the standard Pd/C and high catalytic activity, with a half wave potential (E 1/2 = 0.851 ± 0.006 V vs. RHE) comparable with the value observed for the Pt/C benchmark in the same electrolyte (E 1/2 = 0.862 ± 0.005 V vs. RHE) and significantly higher than that given by Pd/C. Chen et al. prepared the Pd-Ce nano-cubes using a one-step dealloying method of Pd15Ce5Al80 precursors [68]. The abundant pore structure and large specific surface are the key factors affecting the catalytic reaction process. Compared with current commercialized Pd/C catalysts, Pd-Ce shows better electrocatalytic activity in EOR and ORR for the following reasons: firstly, the 3D nonporous structure provided a highly conductive network and accessible open nanopores, which facilitated electron and mass transport during electrocatalysis. Secondly, the alloying of Pd with Ce led to a negative migration from −2.39 eV to −2.00 eV in the d-band center of Pd compared to pure Pd, which weakened the binding to O [69]. In addition, the binding energy to O on the (1 1 1) crystal plane of the Pd3Ce alloy (−1.16 eV) was much lower than that on the (1 1 1) crystal plane of pure Pd (−1.47 eV), which reduced the strength of the Pd–O bond and enhanced the ORR performance in the Pd3Ce alloy [70]. Xue et al. designed and synthesized a RE bimetallic carbide (CeLa2C x -NC) by the pyrolysis of ophthalmic anhydride, melamine, and RE elements (Ce and La) [71]. The half-potential of the RE bimetallic carbide was more positive and prominent than that of the RE monometallic carbide electrocatalysts, which was attributed to the supply of electrons from the RE carbides to the NC, favoring the reduction of O2. In addition, due to its unique high conductivity, the NC carrier can increase the number of active sites on the electrocatalyst, which provides favorable conditions for electron transport [72]. Li et al. prepared Gd2O3-Co/NG [49]. The electrocatalytic performance of Gd2O3-Co/NG toward ORR was evaluated on the rotating disk electrode in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution, in comparison with that of Co/NG, Gd2O3/NG, and commercial Pt/C catalysts. The Gd2O3-Co/NG exhibits a high electrocatalytic activity for the ORR, as judged by positive onset potential (E onset = 0.93 V) and half-wave potentials (E 1/2 = 0.82 V). The half-wave potential of Gd2O3-Co/NG is very close to that of Pt/C catalyst, highlighting the excellent ORR activity of Gd2O3-Co/NG. Upon the introduction of Gd2O3, the ORR activity of Gd2O3-Co/NG is significantly increased compared with Co/NG, where the half-wave potential (E 1/2) of Gd2O3-Co/NG is 100 mV more positive than that of Co/NG and even close to commercial Pt/C (Fig. 6c). To get insight into ORR reaction kinetics, the Tafel slopes were calculated from the polarization curves. Gd2O3-Co/NG has a lower Tafel slope (59 mV dec−1) than that of Co/NG (62 mV dec−1) and Gd2O3/NG (90 mV dec−1), which even is comparable to that of Pt/C (60 mV dec−1), suggesting the favorable reaction kinetics and fast electron transport on Gd2O3-Co/NG electrode (Fig. 6d). The DFT calculation and spectroscopic analysis demonstrate that, owing to intrinsic charge redistribution at the engineered interface of Gd2O3/Co, the coupled Gd2O3-Co can break the *OOH–*OH scaling relation and result in a good balance of *OOH and *OH binding on Gd2O3-Co surface. Their calculations show that ΔG *OOH, ΔG *O and ΔG *OH of Gd2O3 are about 3.56, 2.39, and 0.31 eV; the energy difference between of ΔG *OOH and ΔG *OH (ΔG *OOH − ΔG *OH) is 3.25 eV, in accordance with the well-established linear scaling relation of ΔG *OOH − ΔG *OH ≈ 3.2 eV. It remains somewhat difficult to effectively modulate ORR activity owing to the existence of robust scaling relation, i.e., the balance between *OOH formation and *OH removal. Accordingly, the relatively low activity of Gd2O3 can be seen from its ΔG *OH, which is much smaller than that of Pt (1 1 1) plane (0.79 eV) and the optimal value (0.86 eV). The unfavorable ΔG *OH of Gd2O3 (quite strong *OOH adsorption) also revealed that its potential-limiting step is *OH removal. It was found that all the adsorption of intermediates became weaker after involving Co into Gd2O3 slab. For example, the ΔG *OH of Gd2O3-Co has been considerably increased from 0.31 to 1.51 eV, indicating that *OH removal can be easily achieved on Gd2O3-Co and is no longer the potential-limiting step. The ΔG *OOH and ΔG *O of Gd2O3-Co were found to be 4.25 and 3.18 eV, respectively. Intriguingly, the synergy of Gd2O3 and Co broke the *OOH–*OH scaling relation (ΔG *OOH − ΔG *OH = 2.74 eV for Gd2O3-Co), demonstrating that the enhancement on *OH may not much sacrifice the favorable *OOH binding. For practical application, a rechargeable Zn-air battery employing Gd2O3-Co/NG as an air-cathode achieves a large power density and excellent charge-discharge cycle stability. Pt-based RE alloy nanomaterials have high catalytic performance and renewable performance. Waste Pt-based catalysts can be recycled and reused to reduce resource waste and environmental pollution. However, Pt-based catalysts contain precious metal elements, so the cost is high. Compared with other catalysts, Pt-based catalysts have smaller surface area, which limits the speed and efficiency of the catalytic reaction, and may lead to side reactions, affecting the reaction results and product purity. In practical application, it is necessary to strictly control the reaction conditions and avoid the occurrence of side reactions. 3.2 Hydrogen evolution reaction The small organic molecule electro-oxidation (OMEO) and the HER are two important half-reactions in direct liquid fuel cells (DLFCs) and water electrolysis, respectively, whose performance is largely hindered by the low activity and poor stability of electrocatalysts [73]. Pure hydrogen generation from different chemical reactions such as electrochemical water splitting has been the major scientific challenge that would still deserve further work in order to alleviate the energy crisis [74]. With the development of science and technology, human beings are increasingly damaging the environment. Electrolytic aquatic hydrogen has the advantages of high energy conversion efficiency and no greenhouse gas production. It is an important clean energy source. However, in the process of hydrogen production by hydro electrolysis, the reaction kinetics is relatively slow, so it is one of the most urgent problems to develop a catalyst that can accelerate the speed of hydrogen evolution [75]. The RE alloy nanomaterials provide a new direction for the HER electrocatalyst. Rosalbino et al. reported the ternary alloys Fe-Mo-RE (Fe75Mo20Gd5, Fe75Mo20Dy5, Fe75Mo20Er5, and Fe75Mo20MM5 (MM is a mixed metal with 50.2% Ce, 26.3% La, 17.5% Nd, and 6.0% Pr)) as an electrocatalyst for HER [76]. The Tafel slope of Fe75Mo20MM5 was 103 mV dec−1, which was lower than that of other catalysts. They also reported Fe-Zn-R RE metal alloys, namely Fe80Zn10La10, Fe80Zn10Y10, Fe80Zn10Gd10, and Fe80Zn10MM10 (MM is a mixed metal with 50.2% Ce, 26.3% La, 17.5% Nd, and 6.0% Pr), as HER electrocatalysts. The Fe80Zn10Gd10 has better catalytic performance than other electrocatalytic materials, and the activity in HER is also the highest. Ghobrial et al. prepared amorphous Ni-Nb-Y and amorphous nanocrystalline alloys as electrocatalysts in the HER [77]. The dispersed secondary crystal phase of Ni5Y in the amorphous matrix provided a synergistic effect in HER, and the multiphase structure prepared by mechanical alloying improved its performance. Ni and Nb-Y result in significant changes in bond strength, which affect electron cloud density, intermetallic stability, and catalytic performance. On the grounds of the Volmer-Heyrovsky-Tafel mechanism, the main process is surface catalysis. Thus, the composition and structure of electrode materials are regulated to improve their performance. On this basis, the morphology and properties of the RE alloys prepared by different regulation methods are also different, and the catalytic performance can be enhanced by reducing the overpotential. The Brewer-Engel theory predicts that the HER activity of the catalyst can be improved by combining the left and right halves of the transition metals in the periodic table. Cardoso et al. prepared Ni-Dy alloys and Ni-Sm alloys with RE contents of 5% and 10% for HER, and the HER performance of the Ni-RE alloy with a RE content of 5% was better than that of the Ni-RE alloy with a RE content of 10% [78]. The electrocatalytic activity of these alloys was better than that of pure nickel, which was related to the synergy between the metals involved. As mentioned in the Brewer-Engel valence bond theory, the catalyst performance can be improved by enhancing the binding capacity and stability of the bimetallic alloy, as well as its ability to adsorb and desorb hydrogen. Santos et al. studied the effect of RE elements on the electrocatalytic behavior of Pt [79]. Compared with a single Pt electrode, the hydrogen discharge kinetic performance of the Pt-RE alloy is improved. The addition of RE improved the electrocatalytic activity of Pt, and the HER activity of Pt-Sm bimetallic alloys is higher than other catalysts. In addition, they studied two Ni-Ce alloys with different RE contents in alkaline media, and it was found that the catalytic activity of Ni, Ni0.95Ce0.05, and Ni0.90Ce0.10 catalyst was 51, 56, and 46 kJ mol−1, respectively. Ni0.95Ce0.05 catalyst had the strongest catalytic activity, and the optimum content of Ni-Ce alloy for HER was 5%. To assess the effect of Ce addition on the Ni-based electrodes behavior for the HER, cathodic polarization measurements were performed with Ni and Ni-Ce alloy electrodes in the temperature range of 25–85 °C. Using chronoamperometry (CA), several electrode potentials (ranging from open circuit potential to −1.50 V vs. saturatedcalomelelectrode (SCE)) were applied and the corresponding current density after stabilization was recorded. It could be noticed that for the same potential value, the highest current density is obtained at Ni0.90Ce0.10 electrode. For the same potential value, the highest current density is obtained at Ni0.90Ce0.10 electrode. Alloys’ performance for HER is mainly determined by their surface composition and microstructure, as studied reaction mainly involves surface processes. Both Ni-Ce alloys prepared herein were composed of two phases (Ni and CeNi5) with each phase exhibiting its own characteristic behavior of Hads. Namely, material’s activity for HER is greatly influenced by the strength of the H atoms adsorption at its surface. Considering the “volcano plot” for HER on the transition metals, Ni has intermediate M−Hads bond strength and is therefore expected to show high electrocatalytic activity for HER. Generally, relatively high bonding strength prevents H atoms from leaving the electrode surface increasing the activation energy for the subsequent chemical or electrochemical step. On the other hand, weak bonding of H atoms results in atoms desorption from the electrode surface before their chemical transformation. Rosalbino et al. prepared a crystal Ni65Co29Y6 alloy, and the Ni65Co29Y6 alloy showed better catalytic activity than polycrystalline nickel [80]. Han et al. prepared a LaNi5/Ni-S composite film by using molten salt electrodeposition technology [81]. In the HER reaction, the composite LaNi5/Ni-S films adsorbed many H atoms and oxidized them in an open-circuit state, thus preventing the dissolution of the Ni-S film. The HER property of composite LaNi5/Ni-S thin film was studied, and it was found that the HER property was higher than that of Ni-S thin film. The reason may be that LaNi5 has strong hydrogen adsorption ability and absorbs many H atoms, which makes HER properties better. By an electrochemical method, He et al. prepared a Ni-Co-La2O3 composite-coated electrode [82]. The performance of HER with La2O3 coating is better than that without La2O3 coating, and the current density is 4.7 times higher than that without La2O3 coating, because La2O3 particle doping increases its surface area and the positive synergistic effect of RE decreases its function. By powder metallurgy, Wu et al. prepared a porous Ni-Cu-Ti-La2O3 nanomaterial with a gravel structure, which can be used as an electrode for hydrogen production in the HER reaction [83]. The roughness of the electrode surface increases the surface area of the reaction with the reactants, providing more reactive sites for the HER reaction. HER properties come from the synergistic effect of d-orbital metals as well as the influence of La2O3 and La on the cathode structure. The results show that the HER performance of Ni-Cu-Ti-La2O3 cathodes varies significantly depending on the pH condition. In these electrolytes, the electrodes show excellent HER activity. The HER activity sequence is pH 14.1 (2.67 mol L−1 KOH) > pH 0.1 (1 mol L−1 HCl) > pH 7.0 (saturated NaCl) > pH 8.1 (3.34% simulated seawater). The porous Ni-Cu-Ti-La2O3 cathodes have excellent HER activity in concentrated acid, neutral, and concentrated alkaline electrolytes. It requires an extremely low potential of 132 mV (vs. RHE) to achieve current densities of 100 mA cm−2 under pH 14.1 condition (2.67 mol L−1 KOH). And in pH 0.1 (1 mol L−1 HCl) and pH 8.1 (3.34% simulated seawater) electrolytes, it requires the potential of 240 mV and 594 mV, respectively. The displayed HER activity is superior to that of commercial 20% Pt/C in 2.67 mol L−1 KOH. HER performance is the best under concentrated alkali conditions. Ni base RE alloy is the most widely used alloy materials, which has excellent performance, but the synthesis conditions are more complex, the need for the use of conditions is harsh, suitable for high demand applications. 3.3 Methanol oxidation reaction Fuel cells that directly use alcohols as combustibles (DAFC) are more promising than traditional batteries because of their mobility, stability, and portability. DAFC uses liquid fuel, which is easier to operate than hydrogen fuel cells. Methanol is the most promising liquid fuel, with a simple molecular structure and a high energy conversion rate. Therefore, more and more researchers are paying attention to MOR. The direct methanol fuel cell (DMFC) is a new energy technology with great commercial potential that directly uses methanol, which has the lowest carbon content and the lowest carbon emissions as the fuel, reducing the difficulty of electrochemical conversion [84,85]. However, the input cost of a Pt-based catalyst is too high, and the reaction rate is slow, resulting in surface carbon monoxide poisoning, which greatly limited the promotion of Pt-based catalysts and their widespread use in industrial production. Alloying Pt with cheaper metals can not only reduce the amount of Pt but also improve its electrocatalytic performance, especially the catalytic stability of MOR [86,87]. Zhang et al. synthesized efficient Pt-RE/C (Pt5La/C, Pt5Ce/C, Pt5Pr/C, and Pt5Nd/C) electrocatalysts [88], and the results show that the catalyst has good anti-toxicity to carbon monoxide and can effectively improve the oxidation rate of methanol. Under alkaline conditions, the electron perturbation of RE elements and the oxidation rate of methanol show a “volcanic“ pattern. Among these materials, Pt5Ce/C has the best catalytic activity, with a specific activity of 32.74 mA cmPt −2, 11.1 times that of commercial Pt/C (2.94 mA cmPt −2). The introduction of RE elements causes perturbation of electrons in Pt5Ln, and the optimal electronic structure can be achieved by changing the coupling effect of d-f. By regulating the electronic structure of RE, the adsorption energy can be adjusted to improve the stability of the intermediate, realizing the enhancement of MOR performance and selectivity. An et al. prepared a Pt-Ru-RE/C catalyst composed of La, Eu, Gd, Y, Sm, and Er through the treatment of chemical reduction intermediates, and enhanced the catalytic performance of the Pt-Ru/C catalyst by adding RE elements [89]. Pt-Ru-Eu/C has the highest current density of 71.3 mA mg−1, which is twice that of Pt-Ru/C. Neto et al. prepared Pt-Er/C, Pt-Tb/C, Pt-La/C, Pt-Dy/C, and Pt-Nd/C electrocatalysts using the alcohol reduction method [90]. The methanol electrooxidation performance of Pt-Er/C, Pt-Tb/C, Pt-La/C, Pt-Dy/C, and Pt-Nd/C electrocatalysts is higher than that of Pt/C. The final current values after holding the cell potential at 0.5 V vs. RHE for 30 min are as follows: Pt-Er/C > Pt-Tb/C > Pt-La/C > Pt-Nd/C > Pt-Dy/C > Pt/C > Pt-Pr/C > Pt-Ho/C > Pt-Sm/C > Pt-Ce/C. Diatomic RE alloy nanomaterials have excellent chemical stability, structural flexibility, and electronic properties. The reaction can be regulated by fine-tuning their framework to regulate the electronic properties of their active centers as catalysts. At the same time, the molecular form and morphology of organic matter can be expressed more effectively, to maximize the reaction performance and selectivity. With super chemical stability, it can be stable in strong acid, strong base, and other extreme environment. This chemical stability allows them to fix the catalyst to a surface or other material in order to activate the reactants more efficiently. In addition, it has structural flexibility and can adjust the framework structure to achieve optimal performance according to various application scenarios. Excellent electronic properties can effectively promote various reactions, while identifying the molecular form and morphology of organic materials, in order to maximize the performance and selectivity of the reaction. However, compared with the multi-atomic RE alloy material, the catalytic performance is lower. 3.4 Ethanol oxidation reaction According to the degree of oxidation, the oxidation reaction of ethanol can be divided into complete oxidation of ethanol and partial degradation of ethanol. Converting the chemical energy of ethanol to electricity, direct ethanol fuel cells (DEFCs) are widely used in complete oxidation processes. The selective partial oxidation of ethanol can produce chemicals with high added value. Since the dissociation adsorption of ethanol can produce strong adsorbed species leading to the deactivation of Pt, Pt is not a suitable catalyst for DEFC. However, adding certain metals as co-catalysts to Pt can effectively reduce the degree of deactivation of Pt. Recently, most of the catalysts used in electrocatalytic reactions directly in fuel cells are doped with Pt. The electron synergy between Pt and RE can be enhanced by alloying Pt with RE, and compared with Pt catalyst, composite catalyst has better catalytic activity and stability [91–95]. Xiang et al. prepared the concave cube Pt-La alloy particles, which were synthesized by an electrochemical method in a deep eutectic solvent [59]. The crystal surface has a high refractive index, and the charge transfer between Pt and La occurs, which promotes the high EOR performance of Pt-La alloy particles. Different doping ratios of Pt and La also show different current densities; among them, the peak current density of Pt10La5 reaches 6.28 mA cm−2, which is 1.46 times higher than that of Pt catalyst (4.29 mA cm−2). In EOR reactions, Pt-La alloy particles have higher current density and better durability. Using the same strategy, Wei et al. prepared faceted concave cube Pt90Sm10 alloy nanoparticles with a high refractive index (310) by electrochemical method [96]. Compared with the concave cube Pt nanoparticles and Pt/C catalyst, the concave cube Pt90Sm10 alloy nanoparticles with a high refractive index (310) surface synthesized in this project show higher electrocatalytic activity and ethanol oxidation stability under the combined influence of the spatial and electronic effects of the high refractive index alloy. The Pt-Sm alloy has a stepped surface that can change the free energy of the intermediate to improve the EOR performance. The surface structures of as-synthesized concave cubic Pt90Sm10 alloy NCs were further probed by the electrochemical voltammetry. Comparisons of the CVs of the high-index faceted Pt90Sm10 and Pt concave cubic NCs, as well as the commercial 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst are recorded in 0.1 M HClO4 solution at room temperature. The current peaks between −0.25 and 0.10 V (vs. SCE) are assigned to hydrogen adsorption/desorption. It is obvious that the ethanol electrooxidation on concave cubic Pt90Sm10 alloy NCs gives rise to two current peaks near 0.52 and 0.93 V (vs. SCE), and their peak current densities are 6.44 and 3.71 mA cm−2, respectively (Fig. 7 a and b). These results indicate that the electrocatalytic activity and stability of the concave cubic Pt90Sm10 alloy NCs for ethanol oxidation are superior to that of the concave cubic Pt NCs and commercial 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst. The enhancement in electrocatalytic activity and stability of the concave cubic Pt90Sm10 alloy NCs could be attributed to the synergy of steric and electronic effects from the high-index faceted alloy. DFT calculations were further performed for unveiling the promotional role of Sm on Pt (310) in ethanol electrooxidation. The reaction mechanism of ethanol electrooxidation, in general, consists of two parts: the dissociation of ethanol to acetyl (*CH3CO) and the oxidation of *CH3CO to acetic acid. It could be clearly seen that the total barriers on Pt3Sm (310) are lower than that on Pt (310). The rate-determining step of ethanol electrooxidation on Pt (310) is the oxidation of *CH3CO to acetic acid, in which the barrier was calculated to be 1.21 eV at 0 V (vs. SHE). However, it was found that on Pt3Sm (310), the rate-determining step was the dehydrogenation of *CH3CHOH to *CH3COH with the highest barrier of 0.60 eV at 0 V (vs. SHE) in the whole process; the *CH3CO oxidation was much easier with the barrier being 0.42 eV. Therefore, the 0.60 eV barrier for ethanol oxidation on Pt3Sm (310) is much lower than 1.21 eV on Pt (310), which suggests a higher electroactivity of Pt3Sm (310). Santos et al. prepared Ni and Ce alloy particles with different proportions and studied the relationship between the EOR on the Pt-RE catalyst and the ethanol concentration and working temperature by cyclic and linear sweep voltammetry [97]. In Pt-RE alloys, the ethanol oxidation process is irreversible, but it is reversible in Pt0.5Dy0.5 and Pt electrodes. It shows that all the Pt-RE alloys show better performance for EOR in the alkaline medium than the Pt electrode, and the highest value of the peak current density, j p, is obtained with the Pt0.5Sm0.5 electrode (Fig. 7c and d). On this basis, Corradini et al. studied the Pt-Pr/C catalyst [94]. Pt-Pr/C is synthesized by the improved formic acid method under acidic conditions. The increase in Pr content results in an increase in current density. The electronic effect of Pr2O3 and the dual-function mechanism of PrO2 are the keys to improving the catalytic performance. Pr-based magnetic catalyst used in catalysis has the advantages of high conversion rate, good product selectivity, low reaction pressure, loss of inactive metal, easy separation and recovery, and low cost, which can be widely used in industrial production. However, the reaction temperature is high and the catalyst stability is poor. 3.5 Other electrocatalysis Ammonia (NH3) is a very important chemical substance that plays a very important role in industrial production, energy conversion, and other fields. At present, the preparation is still based on the Haber-Bosch (H-B) method; this method requires high temperature and pressure conditions, with a high energy consumption, and will emit more greenhouse gases. Therefore, it is urgent to find a sustainable NH3 synthesis route that can replace H-B. Compared with the H-B method, the electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) using water and nitrogen as raw materials can produce NH3 at a lower temperature and pressure. The implementation of this project will open a new way to develop a new environment-friendly ammonia gas technology. However, the most challenging problems in the study of NRR reactions are the poor thermal stability of nitrogen molecules and the inactivity of the reaction. The surface layer of RE material has a special electronic structure and a strong binding force with nitrogen. Mao et al. synthesized the Pt-RE (RE = La, Y, and Sc) alloy concave nanocubes (Pt-RENCs) with (410) high-index facets as effective electrocatalysts for NRR [98]. Pt-RE showed good NRR electrocatalytic activity under ambient conditions because of its high low-coordination site density and special electronic effect. The NH3 yield rate and faradaic efficiency (FE) share the same trend. Pt-La (NH3: 71.4 mg h−1 mgcat −1, FE: 35.6%) > Pt-Y (NH3: 65.2 mg h−1 mgcat −1, FE: 26.7%) > Pt-Sc (NH3: 48.5 mg h−1 mgcat −1, FE: 19%) > Pt (NH3: 25.8 mg h−1 mgcat −1, FE: 10.7%). In addition, Pt-RENCS demonstrated selectivity and high stability for high nitrogen reduction to NH3 after 12 h of NRR testing and maintained 90% NH3 yield and FE value (Fig. 8 a and b). Pt-La alloy has a high refractive index surface. A NN bond fracture occurs on the surface of the alloy. The fracture occurs in a voltage range of 0 to −0.5 V, and the transfer of two proton-coupled electrons from nitrogen to *N2H2 is the rate-determining step of NRR. The upward shift of the center of the d-band increased the NRR performance by improving the binding strength of the reaction intermediate on the surface of the Pt-RE alloy with a high index plane. In addition, introducing RE may effectively inhibit the HER process and promote the NRR response.
