Chen et al. reported a synthesis of two-dimensional (2D) SnS nanosheets and the active diatomic Pt-Ce pair (Pt-Ce/SS) [99], and the Faradaic efficiency (FE) of ammonia is studied, It can be seen that Pt0.9/Ce0.5-SS offers a FE of NH3 of 94.12%, with a yield rate for NH3 (Y NH3) of 0.3056 mmol cm−2 h−1 at −0.5 V versus RHE, 1.89 and 1.58-fold of Ce0.5-SS (49.67%) and SS (59.35%), respectively. In particular, such multiple of FE increment is more evident in the potential range in −0.2 to −0.5 V, indicating the more easily motivation for NO3 −-to-NH3 conversion of Pt0.9/Ce0.5-SS in smaller energy consumption, which is promising for industrial-scale applications. Furthermore, benefiting from the great FE of NH3 of Pt0.9/Ce0.5-SS, it could reach a partial current density of NH3 of 109 mA cm−2 at −0.8 V versus RHE much higher than that of Ce0.5-SS and SS NS (Fig. 8a–d). Liu et al. prepared Y and Sc single atoms on a nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) carrier [100], which were represented as Y1/NC and Sc1/NC, respectively. The highest ammonia yield of Y1/NC was 23.2 μg cm−2 h−1, while that of Sc1/NC was 20.4 μg cm−2 h−1 at a lower potential of −0.1 V (Fig. 8e and f). Compared with the Sc1/NC, the Y1/NC has better FE, NH3 yield, and durability, because nitrogen was adsorbed and activated on the RE single atom. Using renewable energy as raw material and converting CO2 into high-value chemical products by the electrochemical method is a prospective solution. Electrocatalytic reduction reaction of CO2 (CO2RR) has the disadvantages of low efficiency and poor selectivity. Consequently, it is essential to design electrode materials with high selectivity and activity for the CO2 reduction reaction [101]. CO2RR can convert CO2 into high value-added chemicals, such as the carbon monoxide, methane, ethylene, and alcohols. Among these, formate is a highly important liquid product and widely regarded as an ideal hydrogen carrier. Therefore, developing efficient catalyst for electrocatalytic CO2RR to formate is highly desirable and important. RE alloys as catalysts have good catalytic activity and selectivity in CO2RR, especially in formic acid formation. This is because RE elements can regulate the catalytic properties of electron transfer, surface acidity, and lattice structure in the reaction. For example, some studies have shown that gadolinium-nickel alloys can efficiently convert CO2 to formic acid at low voltages, with good catalytic activity and stability. At the same time, adding appropriate amount of iron can further improve the catalytic performance. However, there are some problems with the use of RE elements, such as high cost and complicated preparation process. In addition, RE elements are scarce, so more sustainable alternatives need to be developed to meet the needs of practical applications. In addition, most of the metal catalysts for CO2RR to formate are toxic or noble metals, such as Cd, Hg, Pb, and Pd, leading to the environmental pollution or increased production costs. Therefore, Zhang et al. developed an environmentally friendly and low-cost NiZn alloy catalyst for CO2RR to formate [102]. As for a catalyst for CO2RR, the NiZn alloy exhibits the FEHCOO− of 36% ± 0.7% at −0.9 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M KHCO3, and remarkable stability for 40,000 s at −0.8, −0.9, −1.0, and −1.1 V vs. RHE, respectively. The DFT calculation is performed to study the CO2RR pathway for NiZn alloy. The free energy profiles of formate formation, CO formation, and HER on NiZn (1 1 0) and NiZn (1 0 1) are calculated. As for the formate formation, the *HCOO and *COOH are the key intermediates. For NiZn (1 0 1) and NiZn (1 1 0), the free energy barriers of HCOOH formation are 0.30 and 0.08 eV respectively, and both of them are lower than those of CO formation (1.48 and 1.21 eV, respectively). In addition, the free energy barriers of HER on NiZn (1 0 1) and NiZn (1 1 0) are 0.34 and 0.09 eV, respectively, which are higher than those of HCOOH formation. These results indicate that the formation of HCOOH is more favorable on NiZn (1 0 1) and NiZn (1 1 0). In sharp contrast, the NiZn (1 1 0) shows slightly lower free energy barrier of HCOOH formation than NiZn (1 0 1), Thus, NiZn (1 1 0) is considered as the main active surface for HCOOH formation. Although Ni (1 1 1) exhibits lowered ΔG HCOOH (0.13 eV), yet it has the lowest ΔG HER (−0.43 eV), which inhibits the HCOOH formation and leads to severe HER. These results show that the strong *H adsorption on Ni (1 1 1) causes the poor HCOOH selectivity. For Zn (0 0 1), HER is suppressed due to the high ΔG HER (0.8 eV) but the ΔG CO is the lowest (−0.43 eV), which tends to produce CO during CO2RR. Different from Ni (1 1 1) and Zn (0 0 1), the NiZn (1 1 0) exhibits the lowest ΔG HCOOH (0.08 eV) compared to the ΔG CO (1.21 eV) and ΔG HER (0.09 eV), indicating a favorable pathway for HCOOH production. These calculation results illustrate the HCOOH formation pathway over NiZn alloy, agreeing well with the catalytic performances results. Thus, the high cost and the toxic nature hamper their large-scale application at actual operation scenario. Therefore, it is of great significance to explore an environmentally-friendly and low-cost catalyst for CO2RR to produce formate. In the electrocatalytic CO2RR, the *COOH and *HCOO have been considered as the key intermediates for formate formation. Interestingly, modulating the electronic structure of the metal catalyst can tune the adsorption/desorption free energy of the key intermediates, thus affecting the formate selectivity during CO2RR. Metal oxide electrocatalysts based on energy storage and conversion devices of electrocatalysis have been developed rapidly in recent years. Reasonable evaluation of the inherent electrocatalytic activity of catalysts is a prerequisite for finding the best electrocatalysts. The important reactions OER, ORR, HER, and HOR in electrolytic water, fuel cells, and other devices all require highly active electrocatalysts. It is of great significance to establish a reasonable activity measure and evaluate the electrocatalytic performance of catalysts. Electrocatalysis is essentially a surface reaction in which the adsorption and desorption of reactants and products occur only on or near the surface of the catalyst, so the inherent electrocatalytic activity of the catalyst is most often defined as specific activity, that is, current divided by surface area. Therefore, accurate measurement of catalyst surface area determines the reliability of specific activity. At present, the four most used measures of electrocatalytic activity are geometric activity, mass activity, specific activity, and conversion frequency (TOF). Geometric activity is now the most commonly used practical parameter to evaluate the performance of the device, but it does not reflect the inherent activity of the electrocatalyst, because it fails to take into account that the electrocatalytic reaction is a surface process, in which only the surface sites participate in the reaction, and the geometric activity is often affected by the load of the catalyst. Generally, as the load increases, the half-wave potential and the initial potential will move towards high activity. The mass activity depends largely on the size of the electrocatalyst particle (i.e., the number of active sites). Mass activity was obtained by normalizing the current density to the load mass of the electrocatalyst. It can be used as a reasonable parameter to evaluate the inherent properties of different electrode materials in the reaction processes such as lithium batteries. Generally, smaller sized catalysts exhibit higher mass activity because smaller sized particles have a larger ratio of surface atoms to total atoms per unit mass and have many electrocatalytic active sites. Determination of TOF requires both a measurement of current density (which translates into the number of electrons transferred) and a reliable assessment of the number of active sites. Current density can be accurately measured using an electrochemical workstation. However, due to the limited ability of modern techniques to measure the number of active sites clearly, accurate estimation of TOF remains a challenge. Specific activity can represent the intrinsic activity of a catalyst. So far, due to the limited technical ability to characterize the number of active sites, specific activity is the best substitute for TOF and is considered as a reliable indicator to study the intrinsic activity of a catalyst. Generally, three-electrode battery system is used to measure the electrochemical active area (ECSA). Reversible hydrogen electrode is the first reference electrode, saturated calomel electrode (SCE) and Ag/AgCl electrode can be used in acidic and neutral electrolytes, and Hg/HgO is recommended as the reference electrode under alkaline conditions. The intake of the cell is essential to ensure that the current measured is generated solely by the ECSA without interference from side reactions. But the ECSA method is not a suitable method for surface area measurement, and it is actually very difficult to calculate the actual ECSA. Surface areas estimated by electrochemical methods are not necessarily true ECSA because ECSA measurements usually do not detect interactions between electrocatalytic sites and reaction intermediates. At present, the test methods of electrocatalysis also include polarization curve test, Tafel slope test, electrochemical impedance test, stability test, cyclic voltammetry test and so on. CV is one of the most important electroanalytical chemistry research methods. The method is simple and easy to operate and intuitive to parse. It can quickly provide much information such as the reversibility of electroactive substance electrode reaction, chemical reaction history and adsorption of electroactive substance. CV can be used to study the mechanism of electrode process, double layer, adsorption phenomenon, and electrode reaction kinetics. The polarization electrode is characterized by a slow rate of electrode potential change. It is a widely used rapid analytical method for the determination of substances that can be reduced or oxidized on the electrode. Electrochemical impedance technology appears with the development of electrochemical theory and measurement technology, so the most important application field is electrochemical field. Cai et al. reported RuO2 nanoparticles with different degrees of surface selenation, which shows the excellent NRR performance at low overpotential [103]. The NH3 yield rate and FE of RuO2-Se0.18/C reach 12.97 μg h−1 cm−2 and 26.01% at −0.1 V vs. RHE, respectively, which is the highest NH3 yield rate reported at low overpotential. The RuO2-Se0.18/C catalyst also shows excellent stability. The related NH3 yield rate stays constant after 50 h electrolysis. The DFT show multiple promoted-synergism of surface selenation on the RuO2 catalyst. First, optimized surface selenization could drive the adsorption of N2 on RuO2 sites. Second, surface hydrogenation promoted by surface selenization can suppress the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER, competitive reaction), enabling high NRR performance at low potential. Third, optimizing the surface selenization on RuO2 can promote N2 activation (*N2 → *NNH). Fourth, surface selenization can promote NH3 desorption (the rate-limiting step). 4 Conclusions and perspectives The synthesis methods of RE-based alloy nanomaterials are summarized, including the solvothermal method, the calcination method, the electrochemical deposition method, and other synthetic methods. Compared with alloys without RE elements, RE alloys not only have all the advantages of the former, but also show better catalytic performance in reactivity, selectivity, and stability. By adjusting the synthesis method to directly affect the structure of surface atoms, the element composition and bulk phase structure of RE alloys can be precisely designed, to obtain excellent catalytic performance. Compared with the progress of alloy catalysts without RE elements, the synthesis of RE alloys with high specific surface area is still in the early stage of development and faces many challenges and constraints. At present, innovative, and simple synthesis methods of RE alloy catalysts with high specific surface area and small size should be promoted. Synthesis strategies to generate and control the structure of RE alloys and expose more catalytic active sites are of practical significance. The catalytic behavior of RE alloy catalysts is also strongly dependent on the electronic structure of the active site. Some rationally designed alloy structures, including strain effects, have the advantage of increasing the active site of the alloy by chemical etching adjustment of exposed elements. Therefore, it is necessary to explore new methods and milder synthesis conditions to enable these materials to have higher specific surface area. Environmentally friendly, low-cost, and large-scale synthesis methods need to be developed to facilitate the process of materialization. Although RE alloy catalysts have made great progress in the field of energy conversion in recent years, in many cases, the understanding of the mechanism of catalysts in the reaction process is still limited. It is essential to explore and develop advanced characterization techniques, such as in situ electrochemistry and spectroscopy characterization, to carry out further studies to elucidate the origin of catalytic activity and reaction mechanisms. In order to solve the cost problem in industrial applications, the partial or complete replacement of precious metals with non-precious metals without compromising catalytic performance is a promising but challenging task. Due to the unique chemical and structural properties of RE alloys, many examples of precious metal-RE alloy catalysts (partially replaced by REs) show comparable or even better catalytic performance than precious metal industrial catalysts for a given reaction. With the progress of materials science and technology, the alloys without precious metals are expected to receive more and more research attention. The pursuit and development of stable, economical, and environmentally friendly RE alloy catalysts by alloying active non-precious metals and RE metals is an important and sustainable research direction for future cost competitive and practical energy conversion catalysts. Because of the extremely low reduction potential of RE elements and the strong oxygen physical properties, the preparation operation is complicated, the conditions are very harsh, and the experimental repeatability is low. Compared with the abundant synthesis methods of other alloy nanomaterials, as well as the advantages of preparing small size and high specific surface area, the synthesis methods of RE alloy nanomaterials still need to be explored, and it is a challenge to find a synthetic method with mild synthesis conditions that is convenient and green. Moreover, the prepared RE alloy nanomaterials are mainly composed of RE elements and precious metals (Pt, Pd, etc.), which enables the catalyst to have more applications in HER and ORR while the direction of OER and CO2RR is still limited. At the same time, thanks to the development of density functional theory, it is possible to quantitatively describe the “bonding strength” and evaluate the catalytic activity of surface sites by calculating the adsorption free energy of reaction intermediates. Therefore, the exploration and development of new synthesis methods for non-precious metals and RE alloy nanomaterials is important for the electro catalytical application of RE alloy nanomaterials. The use of RE alloy nanomaterials in electrocatalysis is a very promising and attractive research field. Although many RE alloy catalysts show excellent catalytic activity, an in-depth study on the catalytic mechanism is lacking. Therefore, further in-depth exploration should be made through the establishment of theories and models. The in-situ and in-operando high-resolution characterization methodologies are vital to deeply understanding the electro catalytical mechanism and relationship between structure, composition, and performance, which will provide new advanced knowledge for the rational design of earth alloy electrocatalysts. The last decades have witnessed the successful and wide applications of in situ/operando techniques with a deep penetration into electrochemical OER studies. These techniques can identify active centers and reaction intermediates by correlation functions, and study the dynamic behavior of local structures of catalytic centers. The characterization of operando provides a platform for studying the structural evolution and reaction mechanism of OER electrocatalysts in terms of the mechanism of structural transformation in OER process and the structural-activity relationship in understanding the real active site. Therefore, real-time detection of oxidation state and atomic structure transformation of catalyst surface by in-situ characterization technique has important guiding significance for further understanding of reaction mechanism in electrocatalytic energy conversion reaction and further design and optimization of electrocatalytic reaction performance. The conclusion of the structure-activity relationship to guide the design of catalyst should be based on the accurate tracking of catalyst structure reconstruction. The advanced in situ characterization techniques, especially the spectroscopic methods that do not interfere with the working state of the catalyst, have broad application prospects. Meanwhile, the theoretical simulation based on first principles can give the information that cannot be obtained by the experimental methods, and has a guiding role in revealing the structural stability and catalytic reaction mechanism of the catalyst. Understanding the in-situ reconstruction mechanism of catalysts can not only help to construct the correct structure-activity relationship, but also serve as a new strategy for designing high performance catalysts. Another challenging topic is the “synergistic effect”, which is usually used to explain the superior catalytic activity of alloy electrocatalysts. However, the current understanding of this problem is not enough and needs to be followed up. On this basis, more intuitive and clearer influencing factors are found to provide a theoretical basis for improving its performance. At the same time, theory and experiment are combined to deepen the understanding of the catalytic reaction mechanism of RE alloys and develop a new idea for the intelligent design of RE alloy catalytic materials. In addition, the activity of the catalyst directly affects the catalytic efficiency, which is not only related to the activity of the catalyst material itself, the preparation method, the addition of cocatalyst, etc., but also directly related to the physical shape of the catalytic carrier. Therefore, when selecting the suitable catalytic active material, the physical shape of the catalytic carrier must be considered to ensure the high activity of the catalyst. Because the ambient temperature changes at any time, if the catalyst cannot adapt to the temperature changes within a certain range, the performance of the catalyst will be reduced, therefore, the catalyst must be able to adapt to the temperature changes within a certain range, and the price of catalyst with high catalytic activity is relatively expensive, so the design should try to use the catalyst with a long life. For example, when selecting samples, we tend to choose samples with higher purity, and pay attention to the dispersion of metal components in the preparation process. If the dispersion is too high, the catalyst is more likely to be deactivated. With the progress of synthesis method and technology, the pursuit and development of stable, economical, and environmentally friendly RE alloy catalysts through alloying active non-precious metals and RE metals is an important and sustainable research direction for the development of future electrocatalysts with cost competitiveness and practicability. RE alloy nanomaterials have excellent magnetic, optical, electrical, and mechanical properties, and have wide application prospects in many fields. In the future, the development of RE alloy nanomaterials may include the following aspects: (1) Improvement of preparation technology: Development of more refined preparation technology to improve product purity and consistency of lattice structure. (2) Enhanced functional characteristics: The characteristics of the material, such as magnetic field response and fluorescence performance, are enhanced by changing the chemical ratio and microstructure. (3) Expand application fields: In addition to the traditional fields of electronics, information, energy storage, etc., RE alloy nanomaterials can also be applied to biomedicine, environmental governance, new materials, and other fields. (4) Cost reduction: Explore more economical and environmentally friendly preparation methods, reduce the cost of material preparation, and improve the level of industrialization. (5) Play a synergistic effect: combine RE alloys with other materials or technologies to play a synergistic role to achieve higher level of performance and applications, such as nanosensors and nanorobots. coredata.dc:description: With the rapid development of society and economy, the excessive consumption of fossil energy has led to the global energy and environment crisis. In order to explore the sustainable development of new energy, research based on electrocatalysis has attracted extensive attention in the academic circle. The main challenge in this field is to develop nano-catalysts with excellent electrocatalytic activity and selectivity for target products. The state of the active site in catalyst plays a decisive role in the activity and selectivity of the reaction. In order to design efficient and excellent catalysts, it is an effective means to adjust the electronic structure of catalysts. Electronic effects are also called ligand effects. By alloying with rare earth (RE) elements, electrons can be redistributed between RE elements and transition metal elements, achieving accurate design of the electronic structure of the active site in the alloy. Because of the unique electronic structure of RE, it has been paid attention in the field of catalysis. The outermost shell structure of RE elements is basically the same as that of the lower shell, except that the number of electrons in the 4f orbital is different, but the energy level is similar, so their properties are very similar. When RE elements form compounds, both the f electrons in the outermost shell and the d electrons in the lower outer shell can participate in bonding. In addition, part of the 4f electrons in the third outer shell can also participate in bonding. In order to improve the performance of metal catalysts, alloying provides an effective method to design advanced functional materials. RE alloys can integrate the unique electronic structure and catalytic behavior of RE elements into metal materials, which not only provides an opportunity to adjust the electronic structure and catalytic activity of the active component, but also enhances the structural stability of the alloy and is expected to significantly improve the catalytic performance of the catalyst. From the perspective of electronic and catalytic activity, RE elements have unique electronic configuration and lanthanide shrinkage effect. Alloying with RE elements will make the alloy have more abundant electronic structure, activity, and spatial arrangement, effectively adjusting the reaction kinetics of the electrochemical process of the catalyst. In this paper, the composition, structure, synthesis of RE alloys and their applications in the field of electrocatalysis are summarized, including the hydrogen evolution reaction, the oxygen evolution reaction, the oxygen reduction reaction, the methanol oxidation reaction, the ethanol oxidation reaction, and other catalytic reactions. At the same time, the present challenges of RE alloy electrocatalytic materials are summarized and their future development direction is pointed out. In the field of electrocatalysis, the cost of catalyst is too high and the stability is not strong. Therefore, the testing process should be related to the actual application, and the test method should be standardized, so as to carry forward the field of electrocatalysis.
